--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> --- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > The key point that is perhaps not clear is that the
> > lines
> > in the middle are *not* graphs of average
> > complexity, but 
> > rather of *dominant's complexity*.  
> 
> Yes, I understand that.
> 
> That was essentially my criticism.  You're comparing:
> 
> --The complexity of generational champions (averaged
> from 13 separate runs)
> --The max and min complexity each generation (averaged
> from 5 random runs)
> 
> Why not compare:
> 
> --The complexity of generational champions in
> fitness-based runs
> --The average complexity of the entire population in
> random-fitness runs
> 
> The question you pose in section 6.1 is: "[D]oes the
> complexity always increase whether it helps in finding
> good solutions or not?"
> 
> Wouldn't the latter comparison provide better insight
> into answering this question?

First, generation champions are quite different from *dominant
solutions*.  One generation champion is not guaranteed to be better
than another, even if it came later, while dominant solutions are
*always* strictly better.  In other words, we are interested in how
complexity correlates to *strict improvement*, not just how it
correlates to the current champion.

Bearing this in mind, the average complexity of random fitness runs
tells us nothing, because we have no interest in what the average
complexity of something that is *not* strictly better would be.  All
that would show is that when fitness does not improve, average
complexity goes up.  But the whole point of this experiment is what
could happen when strategies *do* strictly improve.

So we want to know, does complexity *have* to go up when dominance
goes up?  That's the question; is it inevitable that complexity would
go up in NEAT?  And the way to know this is to check whether NEAT
keeps around solutions of very low complexity.  Because if it does,
then those *could* be the most dominant solutions.  The random fitness
runs show that indeed NEAT does keep around simple solutions.  Yes,
the average complexity goes up, but average complexity has absolutely
nothing to do with dominant complexity.  Average complexity is just a
measure of the midlevel of the complexities kept in the system.  What
we want to know is, from what range of complexities could a dominant
appear?  Because if it can appear from a full range from very simple
to very complex, then if it actually *does* become complex, it is
because that complexity was beneficial (since, after all, simpler
topologies were available in the population).  

> 
> You're asking if the complexity always increases.  But
> you don't say which complexity you're referring to. 
> If you're referring to the overall complexity of the
> evolving population, it seems very clear that yes, the
> complexity of the population always increases, whether
> or not a fitness evaluation is used.
> 

We're asking about the complexity of *dominant* solutions.  Does it
have to go up?  


> 
> You said something similar in an earlier thread.  I
> still don't see how the concept of "competitive"
> applies to a population with no selection pressure due
> to fitness being applied to it.
> 

Competitive just means that on average you are just as good
as everyone else.  And when your fitness is random, that
is true, i.e. with random fitness all solutions are equal.
In other words, it simulates the time *between* improvements.
It shows that during interim periods, when fitness is not
improving on average, NEAT keeps the simplest topologies
around.  It doesn't lose them.

> It seems to me that simple topologies probably persist
> in a random-fitness run of NEAT due to the effects of
> speciation.
> 

Yes that's why they persist.  That's the whole point.
NEAT keeps the simple stuff around as long as it isn't
doing significantly worse.  That's what's so nice!
GP systems suffer bloat because they can't protect their
simplest solutions.  NEAT protects its simple solutions
in their own species, so they don't bloat.

> 
> > Rather, the claim is that
> > increasing
> > sophistication is a result of increasing complexity,
> > and
> > further that the reason increasing complexity pairs
> > with
> > increasing sophistication is NOT because of some
> > nuance of
> > NEAT; it is because it is fundamentally advantageous
> > to have 
> > more structure in this domain.
> 
> But in section 6.3 you go on to demonstrate that both
> fixed-topology runs and simplification runs show an
> increase in fitness.
> 

The point is certainly not that fitness cannot increase when
topologies are kept static.  Rather, the point is that when
topologies can complexify, that complexification is used to
advantage.  In other words, the system uses increases in 
complexity to increase fitness even though it doesn't have to.

> What that demonstrates to me is that complexification
> is not *necessary* to increase performance in this
> domain, but that it is a more effective way of
> increasing performance in this domain.  Right?
> 

Yes, agreed.  What we are trying to say is that increasing 
complexity helped increase dominance in this domain.

> > But
> > what about when you are NOT stagnating- that's
> > what's 
> > interesting- in that case, adding structure opens
> > the door
> > to more and more sophisticated behavior.
> > 
> > I don't think anyone who uses NEAT really finds that
> > controversial; after all, that's the whole reason we
> > are using NEAT isn't it?  ...because we want to be
> > able
> > to find more and more complex solutions, because we 
> > believe that will lead to more and more interesting 
> > behavior.  
> 
> I certainly believe that NEAT's approach of starting
> minimally and complexifying is a very clever and
> effective way of searching the solution space of a
> given domain.
> 
> But I'd probably qualify this last sentence of yours. 
> I don't necessarily want to find more complex
> solutions...I want to find the best solutions.  That
> includes efficiency.  
> 

Yes of course, I agree.  But what I mean to say is that
in a lot of domains, the best solutions are complex.  So
we need some way of getting there.

> If I start out with a minimal topology in Tic-Tac-Toe
> (99 genes--9 input, 9 output, 81 connections), and
> that topology is sufficient to produce a perfect
> player, I don't want to evolve something with twice as
> many genes.
> 
> I think this may be a intellectual trap of sorts. 
> We're evolving neural networks, which control the
> behavior of a system.  I think it may be misleading to
> assume that an increase in the complexity of behavior
> of an individual necessarily leads to an increase in
> fitness.
> 

I never meant to imply anything like that.   That is
a blanket statement.  Most increases in complexity actually
decrease fitness.  However, note that every high dimensional
space has a global optimum at least as high if not higher
than that of any subspace it completely contains.  
In other words, theoretically, you can only win by adding 
dimensions.  Of course that does not mean you *should* always
do so...what you should do is only add them if you need to.
But in really tough domains, it's clear that it will be
necessary to complexify to some extent.

> [stuff about simple/complex animals]
> So complex behavior doesn't necessarily lead to an
> increase in fitness...wouldn't you agree?
> 

Empirical results only apply to the domain of the experiment.  
Our analysis was of our empirical results.  Of course there
are always going to be different domains.

Your counterexamples beg the question, do you mean
to imply that a system that cannot complexify would 
display a better arms race?  If that is not your implication,
what is your counterexample meant to imply?  The paper
doesn't claim that everything more complex is better in
every case than everything simple.

Very good discussion- I agree these are important issues to think
about.  I apologize for my perhaps overzealous defense of our
analysis- I feel it is actually good practice for me to try to respond
to these kind of questions, especially considering I will eventually
have interviews where similar arguments may come up.

ken
